meta.title: Effects of plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria on the molecular responses of maize under drought and heat stresses: A review
meta.author: Iviwe Notununu, Lucy Moleleki, Ashira Roopnarain, Rasheed Adeleke

div.text: Drought and heat are major environmental stresses that continually influence plant growth and development. Under field conditions, these stresses occur more frequently in combination than alone, which magnifies corresponding detrimental effects on the growth and productivity of agriculturally important crops. Plant responses to such abiotic stresses are quite complex and manifested in a range of developmental, molecular, and physiological modifications that lead either to stress sensitivity or tolerance/resistance. Maize (Zea mays L.) is known for its sensitivity to abiotic stresses, which often results in substantial loss in crop productivity. Bioaugmentation with plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR) has the potential to mitigate the adverse effects of drought and heat stresses on plants. Hence, this is considered a promising and eco-friendly strategy to ensure sustainable and long-term maize production under adverse climatic conditions. These microorganisms possess various plant growth-promoting (PGP) characteristics that can induce drought and heat tolerance in maize plants by directly or indirectly influencing molecular, metabolic, and physiological stress responses of plants. This review aims to assess the current knowledge regarding the ability of PGPR to induce drought and heat stress tolerance in maize plants. Furthermore, the drought and heat stress-induced expression of drought and heat stress response genes for this crop is discussed with the mechanisms through which PGPR alter maize stress response gene expression.

Maize (Zea mays L.) is an essential staple grain crop in Latin America, Asia, and Sub-Saharan Africa, and is primarily used for human consumption and animal feed production (Mahuku et al., 2015). More than 73% of maize growing areas are situated in developing countries, where maize is a staple food crop for millions of people (Shiferaw et al., 2011;Tesfaye et al., 2018). As such, the demand for maize is expected to increase due to the escalations in both food consumption and feed requirements driven by population growth and economic development (Shiferaw et al., 2011). Furthermore, climate change threatens to worsen these existing challenges and further undermine the efforts made to reduce poverty and enhance food security within these regions (Tesfaye et al., 2017). Moreover, the temperatures over Africa are expected to rise even more rapidly, with increases estimated to exceed 2 • C by 2050 (Barros and Field, 2014;Tesfaye et al., 2018). Meanwhile, temperatures over large areas have already exceeded the threshold for maize growth (Cairns et al., 2013;Nelimor et al., 2019). Moreover, global rainfall under future climate change scenarios will either stop pre-season or occur later than usual; worldwide maize production is threatened (Lobell et al., 2011).

Plant response to abiotic stresses is quite complex and manifests as various modifications in plant development, physiology, and molecular activities. These modifications can promote stress tolerance, resistance, or stress sensitivity (Harb et al., 2010). Detrimental effects on plants, such as disruptions in cellular homeostasis, hindrance in growth and development, reduced yield, and plant death, have been reported under heat and drought stresses (Barnabás et al., 2008;Tiwari and Yadav, 2019). To survive, plants must respond and adapt to such stresses. However, they are currently being challenged beyond their capacity to adapt (physically, biochemically, and molecularly) to current climate changeinduced variations in temperature and precipitation patterns (Hussain et al., 2019). This is largely due to the lack of energy and resources required by plants to adapt to such abiotic stress conditions; for example, limited energy for the production of stress response proteins such as late embryogenesis abundant (LEA) proteins or heat shock proteins (HSPs) (Mittler, 2006).

The impact and mitigation of environmental stresses, predominantly from drought and heat, have been studied in isolation, even though under field conditions, these abiotic stresses exist more frequently in combination (Farooq et al., 2012;Lipiec et al., 2013). The co-occurrence of both high temperature and drought has been shown to considerably increase the negative effects on plants, such that the resulting consequences substantially surpass the straightforward additive impact of single stresses (Hussain et al., 2019). Simulation results suggest that climate change scenarios concerning the combination of reduced rainfall and increasing temperatures resulted in diminishing average maize yields by 21%, 33%, and 50%, under 1, 2, and 4 • C warming, respectively (Tesfaye et al., 2018). Lobell et al. (2011) demonstrated that an increase of 1 • C above 30 • C resulted in a 1% decrease in maize grain yield under optimal growing conditions, with a 1.7% reduction observed under drought stress. Alarmingly, reductions up to 40% or more were observed under the combination of drought and heat stresses. Similarly, Meseka et al. (2018) found that while drought stress reduced maize grain yield by up to 58%, the combination of drought and heat stresses reduced maize grain yield by 77%, highlighting the severity of the combined effects of these two stresses. According to Mittler (2006), plant metabolic and molecular responses to the combined effect of these stresses are unique and cannot be extrapolated from the responses induced by each of these stresses applied individually. This is a result of the close association between temperature and plant water status, thus making it impossible to distinguish whether stresses in the field are caused by heat or drought (Pandey et al., 2015;Shahsavandi et al., 2016).

There are many research studies aimed at developing technologies that promote sustainable agricultural practices, which favor increased crop productivity as well as enhanced resistance or tolerance to various stresses (Ali et al., 2011;Ansary et al., 2012;Zafar-ul-Hye et al., 2014;Park et al., 2017). In some methods, beneficial plant-microbe interactions are exploited and these are considered promising areas for the focus of sustainable agricultural developments (Reddy et al., 2014). Beneficial soil microorganisms such as plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR) and mycorrhizal fungi produce large quantities of plant growth-promoting substances (Camele et al., 2019). They are also capable of directly and indirectly influencing the growth and morphology of plants, thereby enhancing development and yield. Consequently, these substances have been successfully applied as biofertilizers or phytostimulants in agriculture (Bano et al., 2013). Another remarkable feature is their ability to support plants in stressed environments. They can protect plants against detrimental effects of various environmental stresses, such as drought and elevated temperatures, to which crop plants are intermittently exposed (Chukwuneme et al., 2020;Hassan et al., 2020;Pereira et al., 2020). The use of PGPR as biostimulants offers an eco-friendly, inexpensive, and ethically-unrestricted approach to solving the crises associated with drought and heat stresses. Therefore, we will provide an overview of the present knowledge about the mechanisms utilized by PGPR to induce tolerance in maize plants under drought and heat stresses, as well as their combined effects. We also highlight the drought and heat stress response genes affected by these abiotic stresses, and how PGPR alters the expression of such stress response genes.

The rhizosphere is a dynamic and nutrient-rich habitat that is directly influenced by plant root exudates and harbors a vast variety of naturally occurring microorganisms (Oleńska et al., 2020). Among these microorganisms, a group of bacteria known as PGPR augments plant growth and development (Sayyed, 2019). This group comprises different bacteria genera including Bacillus, Serratia, Azospirillum, Arthobacter, Enterobacter, Burkholderia, Alcaligenes, Azotobacter, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella. The PGPR exert several positive effects on plants, ranging from direct mechanisms aimed at plant nutrition and plant growth regulation to indirect effects related to their biocontrol activity (Guerrieri et al., 2020). Another remarkable feature is their ability to induce plant tolerance to abiotic stresses (Danish et al., 2020a). As such, PGPR have been applied to seeds or crops to maximize plant growth and yield (Khan and Bano, 2019).

Plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria meet the following criteria: 1) proficient in colonizing the plant root surface or rhizosphere, 2) potential to outcompete other microorganisms that occupy the same physical niche, and 3) efficient in promoting plant growth (Ahemad and Kibret, 2014). Furthermore, based on their interactions with the plant, PGPR can be separated into two categories, namely symbiotic and free-living (Singh, 2018). The former are known as intracellular PGPR (iPGPR) and inhabit root cells or intercellular spaces, while the latter are called extracellular PGPR (ePGPR) and exist outside the plant but within the rhizoplane or rhizosphere (Hayat et al., 2010;Singh, 2018).

paragraphs.title: MECHANISMS OF DROUGHT AND HEAT STRESS MITIGATION IN MAIZE BY PGPR

div.text: The biological and physicochemical properties of the soil are heavily altered during drought and heat stresses, and as a result, the soil becomes unsuitable for microbial and crop growth (Meseka et al., 2018;Tesfaye et al., 2018). However, interactions that occur between PGPR and plants can alleviate such stresses. Several processes have been proposed to promote PGPR-induced heat and drought stress tolerance in plants (Fig. 1). These include modification in root morphology, phytohormonal levels, antioxidant defence, production of bacterial exopolysaccharides (EPS) and 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic deaminase, and the accumulation of several compatible organic solutes, such as sugars, amino acids, and polyamines (Ali et al., 2011;García et al., 2017). The production of HSPs, dehydrins, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) also plays a significant role in the acquisition of drought and heat tolerance (Kaushal and Wani, 2016;Elshafie et al. 2017a, b). Furthermore, PGPR can initiate chemical and physical changes in maize plants, resulting in improved resilience to environmental stresses through induced systemic tolerance (Kannojia et al., 2019). These defence mechanisms can cause substantial alterations in the structural and functional characteristics of plants, leading to abiotic stress resistance (Misra et al., 2017;Sarkar et al., 2018). Plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria can achieve this feat largely because they can respond to stress in similar ways to plants suffering hydric or heat stress when water availability is low or when temperatures are high. Microorganisms sense changes such as increased temperatures and salt concentrations in soil as osmotic variations and respond accordingly (García et al., 2017). Because of their ability to sense these changes in the soil, PGPR are quite specialized in their response to abiotic stresses, which influences how they induce plant growth. Therefore, they are ideal targets for use in improving overall maize productivity.

paragraphs.title: HOW PGPR AMELIORATE THE DROUGHT-INDUCED STRESS IN MAIZE PLANTS

div.text: Drought induces water stress in maize plants primarily because of the limited supply of water to the roots and increased transpiration rates (Lisar et al., 2012). Drought triggers multiple effects that manifest at both molecular and morphological levels, and these effects can be observed at all plant growth stages when water deficit is experienced. Drought stress weakens the metabolic activity of maize, decreases its biomass accumulation, and reduces its photosynthetic rate by decreasing chlorophyll content in leaves, which inevitably leads to a decrease in maize yield (Song et al., 2019). Moreover, drought-stressed plants show decreased cell turgor and water potential in the extracellular matrix and cytosol, resulting in reduced cell size, inhibited growth, and a failure to reproduce (Kapoor et al., 2020). Moreover, oxidative stress caused by the over-production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) as a secondary stress causes wilting, further aggravating the adverse effects of drought stress (Anjum et al., 2017;Hussain et al., 2019) (Fig. 2).

Drought also induces stomatal closure and limits gaseous exchange and transpiration (Agurla et al., 2018). Such unfavorable effects impact nutrient transport, metabolism, and uptake, resulting in decreased leaf area and an altered partitioning of nutrients among different plant organs (Hussain et al., 2019;Kapoor et al., 2020). Changes in cell wall elas-  ticity, homeostasis, and ion distribution in cells can be observed in water-stressed plants, resulting in cell reduction and plant growth retardation. Plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria have unique properties that can aid plants in tolerating drought stress via various mechanisms, as outlined below.

Plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria have been shown to synthesize plant hormones or stimulate endogenous plant hormones that promote plant drought tolerance by inducing plant cell growth and division (Egamberdieva et al., 2017). The application of synthetic and natural plant growth factors has been demonstrated to enhance plant growth under environmental stresses (Vurukonda et al., 2016;Ahmad et al., 2019;Tayyab et al., 2020). These plant growth factors include gibberellin, uniconazole, brassinolide, 1aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic, jasmonic acid, abscisic acid (ABA), indole acetic acid (IAA), salicylic acid (SA), and zeatin (Pavlović., 2018;Ullah et al., 2018). Ethylene and ABA are plant growth-suppressing hormones, whereas others such as auxins, SA, 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate (ACC), gibberellin, and zeatin act as growth promoters; hence, their ratio dictates plant growth response, especially under stressed conditions (Weiss and Ori, 2007). As maize plants are intimately linked with PGPR that reside within plant tissues or the rhizosphere, microbial-derived phytohormones strongly influence plant physiological processes and metabolism under hostile environmental conditions. Indole acetic acid, a particularly well-studied phytohormone secreted by PGPR, has been shown to play numerous roles in growth and developmental events such as cell division, elongation, and differentiation (Asgher et al., 2015;Egamberdieva et al., 2017).

In one study, the co-inoculation of maize plants under moderate water deficit, with two IAA-producing PGPR, Cupriavidus necator 1C2 and Pseudomonas fluorescens S3X, mitigated the negative effects of drought and increased shoot biomass by up to 89% (Pereira et al., 2020). Similarly, maize plants inoculated with Pseudomonas fluorescens strain 153 exhibited increased auxin, ABA, cytokinin, and gibberellin contents in the leaves, while alleviating the effects of water deficiency (Ansary et al., 2012). Similarly, an ABAproducing Azospirillum lipoferum increased the ABA content of maize subjected to drought stress and was treated with fluridone (ABA inhibitor) by 24% (Cohen et al., 2009). This translated to improved root and shoot dry biomass by approximately 100% and 60%, respectively. As this trend was also observed in well-watered inoculated plants, the results imply that Azospirillum was responsible for increased ABA. Abscisic acid is a stress-related hormone that regulates the water balance of plants and cellular dehydration tolerance through stomatal closure and the induction of genes that encode dehydration tolerance proteins (Fernando and Schroeder, 2016;Gowtham et al., 2021). In contrast, compared to maize control plants, those inoculated with Herbaspirillum seropedicae Z-152 (29.5% biomass increase) and Azospirillum brasilense SP-7 (26% biomass increase) exhibited greater resistance to the negative effects of drought stress, with lower levels of plant growth-suppressing hormones, such as ABA and ethylene (Curá et al., 2017). These studies indicate that inoculation with PGPR has the potential to induce tolerance to water deficit stress conditions in maize by regulating phytohormonal content.

The enzyme ACC deaminase, which is involved in mitigating the effects of drought stress in plants by regulating ethylene levels, is known to be produced by PGPR (Zafarul-Hye et al., 2014). However, unlike the direct production of hormones by PGPR, ACC deaminase activity indirectly lowers the level of ethylene by breaking down ACC in plant tissues, thereby reducing the negative effects of ethylene (Gupta and Pandey, 2019). Ethylene is regulated by biological and environmental factors, and its biosynthetic pathways include the conversion of S-adenosylmethionine (S-AdoMet) to ACC (immediate precursor of ethylene) by the enzyme 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate synthase (Hardoim et al., 2008). Plants subjected to stress conditions have reduced root and shoot growth due to ethylene, which endogenously regulates plant homoeostasis. Plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria can sequester and degrade ACC to α-ketobutyrate and ammonia using ACC deaminase, thereby supplying plants with nitrogen and energy (Gupta and Pandey, 2019). This was observed with bioinoculations of maize plants with drought-tolerant and ACC deaminaseproducing Streptomyces pseudovenezuelae and Arthrobacter arilaitensis strains, which increased plant growth and reduced the undesirable effect of drought stress on maize plant (Chukwuneme et al., 2020). Co-inoculation significantly increased maize shoot weight by 81.9%, 44.9%, and 139.5% at field capacity, moderate waterapplication, and zero water application conditions, respectively, while lower shoot weights were observed in the uninoculated plants under the same water regimes. A combination of four P. fluorescens strains (P1, P3, P8, and P14) possessing ACC deaminase activity among other PGP traits significantly increased the ear (44%) and canned seed yield (27%) of sweet corn under limited irrigation compared with controls (Zarei et al., 2020). Similarly, a combination of ACC deaminase-containing PGPR (A. xylosoxidans) and biochar (0.75%) significantly enhanced maize growth and productivity under drought stress. Under severe drought stress, maize plants exhibited per plant increases of 200%, 213%, 113%, 152%, 148%, and 284% in yield, photosynthetic rate, stomatal conductance, chlorophyll a content, total chlorophyll content, and carotenoid content, respectively, compared with controls (Danish et al., 2020b).

Under various environmental stresses, plants produce VOCs which serve as signals that prime and prompt systematic responses within the plant and surrounding ones (Ahemad and Kibret, 2014). In addition, VOCs have been shown to quench ROS, stabilize cell membranes, and play key roles in regulating plant growth, development, and senescence through interactions with plant hormones (Brilli et al., 2019). However, there is little information on how the volatile compounds produced by PGPR improve drought stress tolerance, specifically in maize plants. Nevertheless, Bacillus mojavensis, a close relative of B. subtilis, and an endophytic bacterium of maize has been shown to produce the VOCs acetoin and 2, 3-butanediol, which are linked to plant growth-promoting attributes (Bacon and Hinton, 2002;Rath et al., 2018). Another bacterium, Enterobacter aerogenes, has been found to produce 2, 3-butandiol, which renders maize plants more resistant to biotic stresses (D'alessandro et al., 2014). Similarly, VOCs produced by P. pseudoalcaligenes have been shown to promote plant growth and induce maize resistance to drought stress. Increased shoot (118.2%) and root (133.3%) lengths were observed in plants exposed to the VOCs from P. pseudoalcaligenes, compared to control plants under drought stress (Yasmin et al., 2020). Moreover, induced systemic resistance (ISR) is induced by VOCs via complex mechanisms, including modulation of osmolytes, photosynthetic pigments, phytohormones, and antioxidant enzyme activity.

Osmolytes or compatible solutes have been shown to be involved in enhancing drought stress tolerance in plants. Under water deficit conditions, plants adjust their metabolic processes to accumulate compatible solutes such as polyamines, polyhydric alcohols, sugars, betaines, quaternary ammonium compounds, proline, and other amino acids (Ahemad and Kibret, 2014). Inoculation with PGPR has been shown to mitigate drought stress by modulating the production of these osmolytes in plants. For instance, Sandhya et al. (2010) reported increased relative water content, leaf water potential, and plant biomass due to the accumulation of soluble sugars, free amino acids, and proline in maize plants when they were primed with Pseudomonas putida GAP-P45. Moreover, PGPR-inoculated plants under drought stress conditions have increased concentrations of proline from the upregulation of proline biosynthesis pathways, thereby protecting proteins and membranes from stress by maintaining cell turgor and its associated osmoprotective properties (Sandhya et al., 2010). Inoculating plants with proline-producing PGPR supplements internal proline concentrations (Ansary et al., 2012). Gusain et al. (2015) concluded that the accumulation of proline in plants inoculated with PGPR indicates that plant become more tolerant to drought stress. Maize seedlings inoculated with Pseudomonas pseudoalcaligenes showed increased proline content, by 135% in roots and 102% in shoots, compared to control plants under drought stress. This led to increases in the dry weight of roots and shoots under drought stress by 84.2% and 140%, respectively, compared to controls (Yasmin et al., 2020). Azospirillum (Az19) can produce trehalose (4.4 µg mg -1 fresh weight), another osmoprotectant found in nature, which was 388% greater than that produced by the reference strain (García et al., 2017). Moreover, maize inoculation with Az19 improved plant response to stress, increasing the proline content of roots 11.6 times compared with uninoculated controls. This study demonstrated a positive association between osmotic stress tolerance and trehalose level. It is hypothesized that minute amounts of trehalose are transported to maize roots and stimulate plant stress-resistant pathways (Rodríguez-Salazar et al., 2009). Similarly, maize inoculation with Raoultella planticola YL2 substantially enhanced the accumulation of osmolytes such as choline and glycine betaine, which in turn improved leaf relative water content and dry weight under drought stress (Gou et al., 2015). These studies show that PGPR-produced osmolytes can not only directly affect cell turgor maintenance in maize plants under drought stress, but can also indirectly affect plant drought tolerance by acting as signalling molecules.

Bacteria secrete EPS in high quantities, especially under drought stress conditions, to protect themselves from inhospitable conditions because they are directly dependent on water availability for protein and polysaccharide production (Vurukonda et al., 2016). Thus, the EPS production of Rhizobacteria is thought to participate in mitigating the effects of drought stress. Exopolysaccharides effectively improve the surface attachment of bacteria, biofilm formation, microbial aggregation, and plant-microbe interactions. Exopolysaccharides are released into the soil as slime and capsular materials, which are subsequently adsorbed by clay surfaces via mechanisms such as anion adsorption, cation bridges, Van der Waals forces, and hydrogen bonding (Sandhya et al., 2010). This leads to the formation of a defensive rhizosheath around soil aggregates that decreasing desiccation time and provides an environment capable of holding more water; thus, plant roots are protected from drying for longer periods (Khan and Bano, 2019).

In addition to increasing water potential around plants, EPS also contributes to increased drought tolerance and plant growth by improving water permeability, thereby increasing nutrient uptake by both microbes and plants (Naseem et al., 2018). Naseem and Bano (2014) evaluated EPS-producing bacteria Alcaligenes faecalis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Proteus penneri. They found that treating maize seeds with these bacterial strains, combined with their respective EPS extracts, was able to increase plant biomass, improve soil moisture content, leaf area, and shoot and root length. The strain Bacillus velezensis D3 with ACC deaminase (152 µmol kg -1 h -1 ) and exopolysaccharide activity (83.0 µg mL -1 ) was significantly better in colonizing maize roots, resulting in improved root length (88%) and shoot dry weight (152.4%) (Nadeem et al., 2020). Similarly, the application of two ACC deaminase-containing PGPR strains Pseudomonas syringae S1 and P. fluorescens S2 with full doses of recommended fertilizers significantly enhanced a variety of plant characteristics under dual drought and salinity stresses; these were 19.05%, 58.14%, 28.29%, and 55.14% increases in the number of cobs per plant, plant height, number of grains per cob, and grain yield, compared to the control (Zafar-ul-Hye et al., 2014).

paragraphs.title: Scavenging of ROS and alteration of antioxidant enzyme activity

div.text: Exposure of plants to environmental stresses, such as extreme temperatures and drought, can lead to oxidative stress, which has detrimental secondary effects on plant cells owing to ROS accumulation (Vurukonda et al., 2016). Reactive oxygen species are partially reduced or activated forms of atmospheric oxygen (O 2 ), which are by-products of aerobic metabolism due to the impairment of the electron transport system (Choudhury et al., 2017). Normally, ROS are controlled by a delicate balance between production and scavenging via a highly efficient scavenging mechanism (Hasanuzzaman et al., 2019;Tripathi et al., 2020). Examples of ROS include hydroxyl radicals (OH), superoxide anion radicals (O •- 2 ), hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ), and alkoxy radicals (RO) (Choudhury et al., 2017). Organelles that are primary targets for ROS production under drought conditions include mitochondria, chloroplasts, and peroxisomes (Vurukonda et al., 2016). Uncontrolled ROS accumulation can damage normal cell functions by causing oxidative damage, resulting in DNA nicking, impaired production of amino acids and photosynthetic pigments, and increased lipid peroxidation (Farooq et al., 2009;Raja et al., 2017). The oxidative degeneration of lipids leads to the accumulation of malondialdehyde (MDA), a product of free oxygen radicals (Kong et al., 2016;Morales and Munné-Bosch, 2019). Therefore, MDA is widely accepted as an indicator of oxidative damage through lipid peroxidation. To overcome these effects, plants possess an antioxidant defence system composed of both enzymatic and non-enzymatic components in plant cells (Das et al., 2016). Scavenging of ROS by both components of the antioxidant defence system alleviates oxidative damage in plant tissues. The non-enzymatic component includes α-tocopherol, reduced glutathione, β-carotene, and ascorbic acid, whereas the enzymatic component includes glutathione reductase, catalase (CAT), superoxide dismutase (SOD), monodehydroascorbate reductase (MDHAR), guaiacol peroxidase (POX), ascorbate peroxidase (APX), dehydroascorbate reductase (DHAR), glutathione-S-transferase (GST), and glutathione peroxidase (GPX) (Şen, 2012;Hasanuzzaman et al., 2019).

Plant growth-promoting bacteria are known to produce antioxidants such as phenolic acids and soluble sugars, as well as inducing or suppressing antioxidant defence enzymes in favor of plant endurance under water deficit conditions. For instance, Sandhya et al. (2010) subjected maize plants inoculated with five Pseudomonas spp. (P. putida, P. stutzeri, P. entomophila, P. montelli, and P. syringae) to drought stress. They reported reduced antioxidant enzyme activity in inoculated plants compared to controls (uninoculated), while plant health was maintained, that is, oxidative stress was reduced. A different study by Vardharajula et al. (2011) also showed that maize plants inoculated with Bacillus spp. developed tolerance against drought stress with decreased antioxidant enzyme activity (APX and GPX) compared to uninoculated controls. Similarly, Khan and Bano (2019) showed that the combined treatment of Planomicrobium chinense, Bacillus cereus, and SA significantly decreased the activities of antioxidant enzymes CAT, peroxidase, and APOX by 46%, 63%, and 38%, respectively, in a maize genotype sensitive to drought stress. This translated to increases up to 59% and 75% in the shoot and root dry weight of maize, respectively. In contrast, Pseudomonas inoculation on maize transplant plants under severe water stress increased CAT activity by 50% compared to well-watered plants, alleviating the adverse effects of water stress on the physiological characteristics of maize (relative water content increase by 8%) (Rezazadeh et al., 2019). Soaking of maize seeds in Bacillus megaterium HX-2 suspension increased SOD, peroxidase, and CAT activities under drought by 19.37%, 19.86%, and 10.96%, respectively, leading to a 42.38% reduction of MDA content (Li et al., 2019). The decreased MDA accumulation in PGPR-inoculated maize plants suggests reduced lipid peroxidation under drought stress. This highlights that plant drought tolerance induced by altering antioxidant enzymes can result either from the activation or suppression of antioxidant activity. These studies prove that the alteration of antioxidant activity in plants by PGPR can be beneficial for the enhancing drought tolerance, growth, and development of maize plants.

paragraphs.title: HOW PGPR AMELIORATE HEAT-INDUCED STRESS IN MAIZE PLANTS

div.text: The water status of plants is of great significance under varying climatic conditions. Commonly, plants maintain high cell turgor by stabilizing water content in their tissues, even during sudden minor temperature fluctuations when not much moisture is available. However, continued increase in temperature proves fatal under water deficit conditions (Machado and Paulsen, 2001). Under field conditions worldwide, heat stress generally occurs in conjunction with water stress (Thayil et al., 2020). Generally, the loss of water under heat stress is greater during the day, primarily due to elevated transpiration rates, which ultimately impairs vital physiological activities in plants, and maize is no exception. Instant decreases in leaf tissue water content, altered root conductance, extensively enhanced respiration, and opening of stomata have been observed under heat stress (Fig. 3) (Kandel et al., 2018).

Net photosynthesis is severely hindered at leaf temperatures over 38 • C, and the severity is greater when the temperature increases rapidly instead of gradually (Vinayan et al., 2019). Moreover, high temperature leads to water deficit owing to high evaporation rates, which disturbs cellular homeostasis. The consequent increase in enzyme turnover leads to extensive impediment to plant development and growth, and possibly plant death (Rizhsky et al., 2002). Such effects of heat stress on maize can be reduced by inoculation with PGPR, but there is limited knowledge on how PGPR mitigate heat stress in maize plants.

The role of ethylene in plant responses to abiotic stresses has been widely documented. In general, ethylene level in plants increases in response to heat stress, reducing growth rate as an immediate response to stress (Sharma et al., 2018). However, the intensity and duration of stress can negatively influence the effects of ethylene (Savada et al., 2017). An initial minor peak in ethylene level initiates a protective response in the plant; however, after some time, a second larger peak reportedly induces abscission, chlorosis, and senescence, all of which are detrimental to plant survival (Glick, 2005;Cicchino et al., 2013). Reduction in ethylene level allows the plant to be more resistant to a wide variety of abiotic stresses, including heat (Chatterjee et al., 2017).

Studies focusing on PGPR-mitigated heat stress in maize plants are scarce. Even so, ACC deaminase-producing soil microorganisms can reduce harmful ethylene level through the sequestration and hydrolysis of plant-produced ACC (Dubois et al., 2018). Bacterial isolates producing ACC deaminase have been shown to display heat tolerance. One study has reported that most of the known ACC deaminaseproducing isolates that demonstrate tolerance to high temperature (45 • C) were Bacillus spp. (Misra et al., 2017). Mukhtar et al. (2020) showed that heat stress enhanced EPS production and cleavage of ACC into α-ketobutyrate and ammonia by the ACC deaminase-producing bacterium Bacillus cereus. Moreover, the bacteria could survive temperatures up to 60 • C. The heat tolerance and ACC deaminase-producing ability exhibited by these PGPR show great promise in ameliorating the effects of heat stress in maize plants. The alleviation of heat stress using ACC deaminase-producing PGPR has been shown in plants such as wheat, which, like maize, is also considered a grain crop (Meena et al., 2015).

Exposure to high temperatures induces the production of highly toxic ROS (Sarkar et al., 2018). Reactive oxygen species disturb cellular homeostasis by damaging different cellular and sub-cellular membranes, as well as macromolecules (Foyer and Noctor, 2011). These molecules also disturb the photosynthetic machinery (PSI and PSII) and the stability of cell membranes by triggering electrolyte leakage and autocatalytic lipid peroxidation (Tiwari and Yadav, 2019). Like other abiotic stress factors, these ROS molecules also act as signals that activate the antioxidative defence mechanism to help the plant cope with high temperature stress, protecting cells from oxidative injury (Mittler et al., 2012).

Microbial inoculations reduce cell membrane injury and alter the activity of several antioxidant enzymes, such as APX, CAT, and SOD, under elevated temperatures. Plants usually increase the activity of these antioxidant enzymes as well as antioxidative compounds, such as ascorbic acid, to alleviate oxidative damage in plant tissues resulting from ROS. However, intense or prolonged heat stress in maize plants reportedly reduces antioxidant activity (Kandel et al., 2018). Amelioration of heat stress mediated by PGPR appears to be associated with reduced ROS accumulation and membrane damage, enhanced chlorophyll content, upregulation of an array of redox enzymes, and accumulation of osmolytes, which improve overall plant thermotolerance (Farooq et al., 2009). One way to mitigate ROS accumulation is to augment the content of phenols, which constitute the non-enzymatic antioxidants of the plant (Vardharajula et al., 2011). Plants can accumulate phenolic compounds in response to heat stress, which are able to scavenge ROS (Soengas et al., 2018). Phenolic compounds help inhibit the action of oxidizing enzymes by forming complexes with metals, which catalyze oxygenation reactions (Król et al., 2014). Heat stress has also been shown to enhance the exogenous production of antioxidants by microorganisms. Bacillus isolates (HT1, HT3, and HT4) and Pseudooceanicola marinus HT2 subjected to heat stress (56 • C) exhibited increased levels of flavonoids and polyphenols in all strains and glutathione in HT2 (Hassan et al., 2020). These microbes also displayed increased CAT, SOD, GPX, and POX activity under heat stress, compared to the control. Additionally, Enterobacter spp. have previously been shown to produce antioxidants, including ascorbic acid (Ghosh et al., 2015). As such, exogenously produced PGPR antioxidants have the potential to reduce oxidative damage in heat-stressed maize. Furthermore, Bacillus safensis, Ochrobactrium pseudogrignonense, and Bacillus cereus have been shown to activate antioxidant signalling in plants under heat stress, leading to enhanced redox enzyme activity (Khan et al., 2020;Mukhtar et al., 2020).

While numerous studies have been conducted on drought stress, to the best of our knowledge, there are no documented studies that report the effects of PGPR on the antioxidant enzymes of maize subjected to heat stress. Moreover, the exogenous application of antioxidants in maize under heat stress has been shown to mitigate the detrimental effects of the stress. Exogenous seed priming with, and foliar application of, ascorbic acid (non-enzymatic antioxidant) in late-planted spring maize increased the activity of SOD, CAT, and POX under heat stress, translating to improving grain yield by 24.7%-24.9% in 2007 and 18.5%-24.0% in 2008 (Ahmad et al., 2017). Likewise, exogenously applied ascorbic acid improved SOD, CAT, and POX activities under heat stress by 6%, 47%, and 11% in maize planted on the normal planting date and by 3%, 42%, and 11% in late-planted maize, respectively (Misra et al., 2017). This translated to a grain yield increase of 3% and 24% in normal-and late-planted maize, respectively (Iqbal M M et al., 2020). These reports highlight the potential of PGPR to produce antioxidants to ameliorate heat stress effects in maize plants.

Phytohormones act as chemical messengers to coordinate various signal transduction pathways between cells during abiotic stress response (Sabagh et al., 2020). These hormones include ABA, gibberellin, ethylene, brassinosteroids, SA, jasmonates, cytokinins, and auxins such as IAA (Wani et al., 2016). Among these, IAA is the most widely used and studied auxin produced by plants and bacteria. It plays a role in root development, seed germination, apical dominance, cell division, and differentiation (Hakim et al., 2021). It also influences processes such as biosynthesis of metabolites and photosynthesis, playing a role in stress resistance (Sattiraju et al., 2019). Heat stress is reported to suppress the biosynthesis of phytohormones such as IAA and gibberellin by downregulating genes involved in their biosynthesis, thus hampering their functions (Wu et al., 2016;Sharma et al., 2018).

The exogenous application of phytohormones has also been shown to help alleviate the destructive effects of heat stress on maize. For instance, the exogenous application of SA resulted in significantly enhanced parameters of plant growth in late-planted spring maize, such as grain yield (27%), growth rate (13%), photosynthetic pigments (17%), relative water content (16%), and the membrane stability index (26%), compared to the control (Iqbal H et al., 2020). Ahmad et al. (2017) also observed improved morphological, biochemical, physiological, and yield-related traits, such as grain yield (19.3%-21.2%) and grain quality of late springsown maize in 2007 and 2008, when SA was exogenously applied through seed priming. Moreover, in both years, higher peroxidase (8.7%-60.3%), CAT (39.4%-74.3%), and SOD (21.0%-31.1%) were reported in plants primed with SA than in control, indicating that the antioxidant system plays a role in SA-mediated plant thermotolerance (Ahmad et al., 2017). The exogenous application of ABA in heatstressed maize induces HSP production, strengthening PSII heat tolerance (Maestri et al., 2002;Tao et al., 2016).

Reports suggest that more than 80% of microbes residing in the rhizosphere can synthesize and release phytohormones (Oleńska et al., 2020). In a similar way to their drought stress response, PGPR can produce phytohormones under heat stress, which have been shown to help plants gain thermotolerance (El-Daim et al., 2014). Pseudomonas putida AKMP7 can produce IAA and gibberellins under both ambient (28 • C) and high (50 • C) temperatures (Ali et al., 2011), with 61.9 and 32 mg mg -1 of IAA, respectively and 0.43 and 0.18 mg mg -1 of gibberellins, respectively. Likewise, B. cereus SA1 can tolerate a temperature up to 45 • C and produce significant amounts of IAA (2.4 µg mL -1 ) and gibberellins (1.3 µg mL -1 ) (Khan et al., 2020). Bacillus tequilensis SSB07 has also demonstrated tolerance of temperature up to 35 • C and can produce both bioactive and inactive gibberellins (0.002 4-0.022 5 ng mL -1 ) as well as IAA (0.42 µg mL -1 ) and ABA (0.43 µg mL -1 ) (Kang et al., 2019). In a study conducted by Park et al. (2017), high levels of jasmonic acid, gibberellins (GA4, GA7, and GA12), and IAA were recorded in heat-stressed plants inoculated with Bacillus aryabhattai SRB02.

Such physiological changes are also conventional markers for integrated stress response (Misra et al., 2017), consequently suggesting that bacteria-mediated resistance to heat stress in plants is associated with ISR induction (Dimkpa et al., 2009). Few studies have been conducted on the amelioration of heat stress in maize using IAA-producing PGPR. However, IAA-producing microbes have been shown to mitigate heat stress effects on other plants, such as wheat and tomato seedlings (Ali et al., 2011;El-Daim et al., 2014;Khan et al., 2020;Mukhtar et al., 2020). The heat stress-ameliorating effects of IAA-producing PGPR on plants shows promise, with these effects potentially applicable to heat-stressed maize plants.

paragraphs.title: EFFECTS OF DROUGHT, HEAT, AND THE CONCU-RRENT STRESSES ON MAIZE STRESS RESPONSE GENES

div.text: Temperatures above the normal optimum and water below the required amount are interpreted as heat and drought stresses by all living organisms. Under field conditions, these two abiotic stresses are more prevalent in combination than in isolation (Prasad et al., 2008). In addition, the combined effects of heat and drought stresses have unique effects on various plant physiological, developmental, growth, yield, and genetic parameters, suggesting that plants have different response mechanisms to combined stresses than individual stresses (Jagtap et al., 1998). However, research on how combined stresses affect crop productivity is comparatively lacking, relative to the research effort on individual effects, especially in maize. Even so, the few studies that aimed to characterize the consequences of both heat and drought stresses on plants reported significantly negative effects on the growth and productivity of crops under the combined effects of these stresses, compared to each type of stress in isolation (Jiang and Huang, 2001;Prasad et al., 2008). Alterations in plant molecular mechanisms such as transcript expression, accumulation of lipids, and photosynthesis have been reported under the combined stresses of drought and heat (Table I) (Rizhsky et al., 2004).

Various studies have been conducted to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of drought and heat stresses in plants (Hu et al., 2010;Zhao et al., 2016;Hussain et al., 2019). The genes regarded as regulators that influence the heat and drought resistance of plants have been identified and wellstudied. Regulatory proteins encoded by these genes include heat stress transcription factors, HSPs, dehydrins, LEA proteins, myelocytomatosis and myeloblastosis transcription factors, and transporter proteins among others (Min et al., 2016). The typical regulation of HSPs in plants during heat stress is illustrated in Fig. 4.

During drought stress alone, suppression subtractive hybridization conducted on maize plants showed a significant upregulation of 113 and 67 expressed sequence tags (ESTs) in roots and leaves, respectively, with 57 of the ESTs being common to both (Zheng et al., 2004). Moreover, the induced transcripts in the roots and leaves increased as  Zhao et al., 2016 Upregulation of 1 136 genes and downregulation of 689 genes in the ear, upregulation of 2 357 genes and downregulation of 1 402 genes in the ear leaf, upregulation of 2 627 genes and downregulation of 3 565 genes in the kernel  time progressed (2-6 h), compared to that observed during the initial drought stress exposure. For instance, the GST7 gene (encoding GST) involved in ROS detoxification had 10-fold greater expression in root tissues at the 6th h than at earlier stages of the stress response. Similarly, glutathione reductase transcripts exhibited increased expression in both roots (1.7-and 2-fold) and leaves (1.7-and 2.2-fold) of maize plants after longer (10 and 12 d, respectively) exposure to drought stress (Aslam et al., 2015). The DBF1 gene (encoding DNA replication-related element-binding transcription factor) showed a 7-fold increase after 2 h, whereas the target gene of a Ras-related protein (rab17) showed an 18-fold increase after 6 h of drought stress (Zheng et al., 2004). Additionally, after 24 and 72 h of drought stress, the expression of rab17 was 24-and 56-fold higher, respectively, compared to unstressed maize plants (Zheng et al., 2004). Rab17 is a group 3 LEA protein linked to the induction of drought resistance and cell shrinkage prevention due to water loss (Aslam et al., 2015). The expressions of EMB564 and MLG3, which are group 1 and 2 LEA proteins, respectively, have previously been described under water deficit conditions (Aslam et al., 2015). Using reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR), the transcription level of ZmbZIP4 was rapidly and strongly induced by polyethylene glycol (11-fold after 2 h) and heat (10-fold after 6 h) treatments (Ma et al., 2018). The transcription factor gene ZmbZIP4 is a positive regulator of plant abiotic stress responses and is involved in maize root development. In maize, the ZmDBF3 member of the dehydration-responsive element-binding protein (DREB) transcription factor, which acts as a regulatory factor in multiple stress response pathways, is induced by drought (22-fold after 1 h) and high temperature (34-fold higher after 5 h) (Zhou et al., 2016).

One study applied comparative transcriptomics analysis to understand the differential expression of genes (DEGs) in maize ears at the V9 stage, kernels, and ear leaf at the 5th day after pollination under drought stress conditions. The study identified the expression of more transcripts in the ear and kernel than in the ear leaf. A total of 1 136 genes were upregulated and 689 downregulated in the ear, 2 357 were upregulated and 1 402 downregulated in the ear leaf, and 2 627 were upregulated and 3 565 downregulated in the kernel (Wang et al., 2019). When comparing the DEGs in different tissues, the kernel shared 662 DEGs with the ear and 1 014 with the ear leaf, while only 141 DEGs were shared between the ear and ear leaf. Some of these genes are involved in ABA-and N -acetylcysteine-mediated signalling pathways, osmotic protective substance synthesis, and protein folding response.

Transcriptional analysis has shown that maize exhibits increased transcript expression of low-and high-molecularweight HSPs in response to drought and heat stresses (Hu et al., 2010). Using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS), it was observed that sHSP26, sHSP17.4, and sHSP17.2 were highly expressed in maize leaves responding to drought stress (Hu et al., 2010). Lund et al. (1998) also reported sHSP22 in maize, which showed a dramatic increase in expression under heat stress and a decline after stress mitigation. This indicates that maize mitochondrial HSP22 may play a protective role against heat stress. However, no changes in the expression level of the higher molecular weight HSP70 were observed under heat stress (Lund et al., 1998). This protein was highly expressed under both heat-stressed and non-stressed conditions, likely due to the constitutive folding of proteins to afford pre-emptive protection against stressful events (Lund et al., 1998).

On the other hand, the analysis of the plant transcriptome under combined heat and drought stresses depicts novel defence reaction patterns that include a partial combination of multiple multigene defence pathways (Rizhsky et al., 2002(Rizhsky et al., , 2004;;Zhao et al., 2016). Furthermore, the characterization of plant physiological responses under heat, drought stress, or their combined effects shows that the combination of stresses presents multiple distinctive aspects. Some of these are the simultaneous occurrence of low photosynthesis with high respiration, and high leaf temperatures with the closing of stomata (Mittler, 2006). There is a strong correlation between the physiological properties and transcriptome profiling of plants subjected to drought or heat stress individually or in combination; however, there is a gap in the literature on how maize plants respond to the combination of drought and heat stresses at the transcriptomic level. Zhao et al. (2016) found that inducing drought stress or a combination of heat and drought stresses in maize commonly downregulated RAB17, GST6, ABA-responsive protein, MTN3, aquaporin PIP2-6, and dehydrin proteins. Furthermore, heat stress and combined stress conditions commonly upregulated 36 proteins, of which 20 were HSPs, which included 14 small HSPs (sHSPs). Drought stress only slightly affected these proteins. The study also found that under combined stresses, ABA stress and ripening-induciblelike protein, ethylene-responsive protein, and ABA stress ripening protein 2 were highly expressed (Zhao et al., 2016). However, under heat stress, these proteins were downregulated. Hussain et al. (2019) showed an increased regulation of SOD under combined drought and heat stresses, compared with their individual effects on two maize cultivars (Xida 889 and Xida 319). However, CAT and APX regulation in Xida 319 and Xida 889 were significantly decreased under stress conditions, compared to the control condition. Moreover, CAT, peroxidase, and APX were most severely reduced under heat stress, followed by under drought and combined drought and heat stresses. This emphasizes the fact that plant molecular and metabolic responses to the combined effects of heat and drought stresses are unique to the responses observed when each of the stresses is applied individually. In contrast, Zhou et al. (2017) concluded that combined stresses do not always increase damage to plants, as was previously thought.

paragraphs.title: REGULATION OF DROUGHT AND HEAT STRESS RESPONSE GENES BY PGPR

div.text: The PGPR employed to mitigate abiotic stresses have been shown to induce ISR (Vargas et al., 2014). This suggests that the primed physiological state of an inoculated plant could explain the increased tolerance to abiotic stresses (Dimkpa et al., 2009). The priming phenomenon has not been fully elucidated at the molecular level. However, its strong relationship with the accumulation of inactive signalling proteins activated and transduced under stress has been shown. This is especially true for future exposure of the plant to the same stress (Park et al., 2017). This enables PGPR to alter the transcriptional expression of plant genes, thereby inducing tolerance to abiotic stresses. Evidence from a few studies is detailed in Table II.

Inoculation of maize grown under drought conditions with Herbaspirillum seropedicae Z-152 and Azospirillum brasilense SP-7 led to decreased expression of the ZmVP14 gene, which confers drought stress resistance and is implicated in ABA biosynthesis (Curá et al., 2017). In addition, maize plants inoculated with Serratia liquefaciens KM4 exhibited tolerance to osmotic stress. This was associated with the increased expression of stress-related genes such as SOD, CAT, APX, RBCS (encoding ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase small subunit), RBCL (encoding ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase large chain), H + -PPase (encoding H + -translocating inorganic pyrophosphatase), HKT1 (encoding sodium transporter), and NHX1 (encoding Na + /H + antiporter), and downregulation of NCED (encoding 9-cisepoxycarotenoid dioxygenase), which is the primary gene involved in ABA biosynthesis (El-Esawi et al., 2018). The response of plants to drought is usually comparable to that to salinity, namely the osmotic effect in the initial phase of salinity stress. Another study showed that Bacillus megaterium, which can improve drought tolerance in clover plants, also improved osmotic stress tolerance in maize plants. Moreover, the expression of plasma membrane intrinsic protein genes, including ZmPIP1;1, ZmPIP2;1, and ZmPIP2;5, was reduced in inoculated leaves compared to uninoculated leaves. The opposite was observed for ZmPIP1;2 expression (Marulanda et al., 2010). These studies show that PGPR can induce abiotic tolerance by modifying the transcriptional expression of maize stress response genes. Even so, it must be noted that there are few published studies on this topic, especially on maize plants.

To highlight the potential of PGPR to induce plant drought and heat stress tolerance by influencing plant stress response genes, we also describe wheat, Arabidopsis, pepper, soybean, and sugarcane. Paenibacillus polymyxa B2 increases Arabidopsis thaliana plant resistance to drought stress (Timmusk and Wagner, 1999). Furthermore, the expression of ERD15, a drought response gene, was elevated in treated plants, relative to untreated control plants (Timmusk and Wagner, 1999). In pepper plants inoculated with Bacillus licheniformis K11 and subjected to water deficit conditions, differential display polymerase chain reaction (DD-PCR) and 2-D polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (2D-PAGE) showed six differentially expressed stress proteins (Lim and Kim, 2013). Among these, Capsicum annuum dehydrin (Cadhn), sHSP, and Capsicum annuum pathogenesis-related protein 10 (CaPR-10) showed a greater than 1.5-fold increase in inoculated plants, relative to controls (Lim and Kim, 2013). In pepper plants inoculated with Bacillus sp. TW4 and subjected to osmotic stress, the abiotic stress-inducible genes caLTPI (encoding a lipid transfer protein) and caACCO (encoding ACC oxidase) associated with ethylene metabolism were downregulated (Sziderics et al., 2007). The study suggested that this might be attributed to the ACC deaminase activity of Bacillus sp. TW4. Using qPCR to detect stress-related gene expression in wheat leaves, transcripts of S-AdoMet synthase 1 (SAMS1), ascorbate peroxidase 1 (APX1), and HSP17.8 were upregulated when plants were inoculated with A. brasilense NO40 and Bacillus amyloliquefaciens 5113, which in turn mitigated the negative effects of drought stress (Kasim et al., 2013). Bacillus aryabhattai SRB02 was shown to significantly promote the growth of soybean and greatly ameliorate the effects of heat stress (Park et al., 2017). At the transcriptional level, qPCR analysis of inoculated plants subjected to heat stress reportedly showed significantly greater accumulation of GmIAA16 and GmIAA9 transcripts. Both these genes encode the Aux/IAA transcriptional repressor proteins involved in auxin signalling (Park et al., 2017). Moreover, transcripts of two soybean cytokinindehydrogenase genes, GMCKX04 and GmCKX07 (encoding cytokinin dehydrogenase proteins, which are involved in the degradation of the cytokinin phytohormone in plants), increased in plants inoculated with B. aryabhattai SRB02 under both high-temperature and normal conditions (Park et al., 2017).

Pseudomonas chlororaphis O6 can ameliorate drought stress effects in A. thaliana plants by altering the expression of drought signalling response genes (Cho et al., 2013). Through microarray analysis, upregulation of VSP1, pdf-1.2, jasmonic acid-marker genes, HEL, PR-1, ethylene-response gene, and SA-regulated genes were observed in the inoculated plants (Cho et al., 2013). Using Illumina sequencing, the inoculation of sugarcane subjected to water deficit conditions with Gluconacetobacter diazotrophicus PAL5 activated ABA-dependent signalling genes, resulting in droughttolerant plants (Vargas et al., 2014). Such transcriptional changes are also typical indicators of ISR, suggesting that there is a strong correlation between ISR and PGPR that mediate plant tolerance to abiotic stresses. These studies demonstrate that PGPR confers beneficial effects on maize and other important crops, primarily at the molecular level.

The knowledge gained over the past decades has helped to understand key features regarding the mode of action of plant-PGPR interactions conferring abiotic stress tolerance of plants, but major knowledge gaps remain. Drought stress effects on plants as well as how PGPR-ameliorated drought stress affects the physiological, growth, developmental, yield, and genetic parameters of maize have been well documented. However, the effects of heat, as a single stress or in combination with drought, on maize are not clear. Likewise, studies demonstrating how PGPR mitigate these stresses in maize plants are scarce.

A plethora of molecular techniques, such as metatranscriptomics, metabolomics, and metaproteomics, are becoming more accessible for monitoring plant responses to abiotic stresses. Furthermore, these techniques are expected to improve tremendously, making it possible to more precisely determine how PGPR induce plant tolerance to drought, heat and their combinatory stresses by influencing plant molecular signalling and stress response pathways. Additionally, stress response genes and proteins such as antioxidant enzymes, heat stress transcription factors, high-and low-molecularweight HSPs, LEA proteins, and dehydrins are critical for maize plants acquiring tolerance to drought, heat, and their combined stresses. As such, investigating how these stress response genes are altered under PGPR-mitigated combined drought and heat stresses should be a priority. This in turn will positively affect agricultural productivity by mitigating the negative effects of climate change in the coming decades. The evaluation of how PGPR imparts drought and heat tolerance to plants is still at its early stages. In essence, PGPR that are capable of inducing plant resistance to combinations of abiotic stresses, especially those that mimic field conditions, should be considered for future research programs that promote sustainable agriculture. Moreover, understanding the relationships between plants, associated microbes, and the environment is a promising approach toward addressing the negative effects of climate change on maize production.
